fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A monad on a category C is a monoid in the endofunctor category C^C. Explicitly, this consists of:

fr:ul.fr:li: a unit natural transformation 1_C\xrightarrow {\eta } T from the identity functor;
a multiplication natural transformation T^2\xrightarrow {\mu } T.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Because the monoidal structure of the endofunctor category is strict, the monoid laws take the form of commutativity of the following diagrams of whiskered composites:

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Category theory in context

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suitable for advanced undergraduates and graduate students in mathematics, the text provides tools for understanding and attacking difficult problems in algebra, number theory, algebraic geometry, and algebraic topology. Drawing upon a broad range of mathematical examples from the categorical perspective, the author illustrates how the concepts and constructions of category theory arise from and illuminate more basic mathematical ideas. Prerequisites are limited to familiarity with some basic set theory and logic.

fr:title.text: Kleisli category is an initial resolution

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Kleisli category is an initial resolution

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given an object c\in C_T, which is just an object in c, the compatibility condition JF_T = F requires that Jc = Fc. A map c\overset {f}{\rightsquigarrow } c' in C_T is the transpose under the adjunction F_T\dashv U_T of the underlying map c\xrightarrow {f} Tc' in C, so since the map J must commute with transposition, Jf must be the transpose of f under F\dashv U. We can compute this explicitly formula for adjoint maps: it is the map Fc\xrightarrow {Ff} FUFc'\xrightarrow {\epsilon F_{c'}} Fc'. All these choices are forced, establishing uniqueness.

fr:title.text: Eilenberg-Moore category is a terminal resolution

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Eilenberg-Moore category is a terminal resolution

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: It remains to show uniqueness. First, since U^TK = U, Kd must be an algebra TUd\xrightarrow {\gamma } Ud with carrier Ud, and furthermore must take maps d\xrightarrow {f} d' to Uf; the only issue is the identity \gamma = U\epsilon _d. By definition of a morphism of adjunctions, letting \epsilon ^T be the counit of F^T\dashv U^T, it must hold that K\epsilon = \epsilon ^TK, but by the construction of the Eilenberg-Moore category as a resolution, \gamma = (\epsilon ^TK)_d = K\epsilon _d = U\epsilon _d, as desired.
The Kleisli category C_T of a monad (T, \eta , \mu ) over a category C is the category with:

fr:ul.fr:li: morphisms x\to y, written x\rightsquigarrow y the morphisms x\to Ty in C;
composition of x\overset {f}{\rightsquigarrow }y\overset {g}{\rightsquigarrow }z the composite x\xrightarrow {f}Ty\xrightarrow {Tg}T^2z\xrightarrow {\mu _z} Tz in C;
identities x\overset {1_x}{\rightsquigarrow } x the units x\xrightarrow {\eta _x} Tx of T.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: (Associativity and unitality follow from the monad laws.)

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: To show the adjunction, note that we have natural isomorphisms C_T(F_Tx, y)\cong C(x, Ty)\cong C(x, U_Ty), where the first is the definition of a Kleisli morphism and the second is the definition of U_T on objects.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Eilenberg-Moore category C^T of a monad T is the category whose objects are T-algebras and whose morphisms are algebra homomorphisms.

Let (T, \eta , \mu ) be monad on a category C. Then the category of resolutions of T \operatorname *{Adj}_T has as objects resolutions of T, and as morphisms morphisms of adjunctions whose action on C is by the identity; note that the additional compatibility condition 1_C\eta = \eta 1_C from the definition of morphism of adjunction is satisfied by construction, because both adjunctions have the same unit.

Let (T, \eta , \mu ) be a monad on a category C and x\in C an object. Then the free algebra on x is the map T^2x\xrightarrow {\mu _x} Tx. The free algebra functor C\xrightarrow {F^T} C^T from C to the Eilenberg-Moore category of T takes a map x\xrightarrow {f} y to the homomorphism Tx\xrightarrow {Tf} Tb.
Let T be a monad on a category C. A resolution of T is an adjunction which induces T.
A monoidal category is strict if its associators and unitors are each identities.
An endofunctor is an endomorphic functor, i.e. a functor whose domain and codomain agree. The endofunctor category over a category C is the functor category C^C.
A monoid in a monoidal category C consists of:

fr:ul.fr:li: a multiplication morphism m\otimes m\xrightarrow {\mu } m.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must make the following unit and associativity diagrams commute:
Let C be a category. The identity functor C\xrightarrow {1_C}C sends each object and morphism to itself.

A natural transformation F\xrightarrow {\alpha } G between functors C\xrightarrow {F,G} D consists of, for every object x\in C, a morphism \alpha _x: Fx\to Gx (the components) such that, for every morphism x\xrightarrow {f}y in C, the following diagram commutes:
A category C consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: a collection of objects, overloadingly also called C;
for each pair of objects x,y\in C, a collection of morphisms C(x, y);
for each object x\in C, a designated identity morphism x\xrightarrow {1_x} x;
for each pair of morphisms x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g} z, a designated composite morphism x\xrightarrow {gf} z.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must satisfy the following axioms:

fr:ul.fr:li: unitality: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y, 1_yf = f = f1_x;
associativity: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g}z\xrightarrow {h}w, h(gf) = (hg)f.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In other words, the following diagrams must commute:
